stem: The nurse is monitoring a client in various types of traction. Match each traction type with its primary nursing consideration.

columns.text: Frequent skin assessments of the heel and popliteal space; booting.
Pin site care using aseptic technique and monitoring for purulence.
Keeping a wrench or screwdriver taped to the vest at all times.
Maintaining the buttocks slightly off the mattress to ensure pull.

rationale.correct: Traction safety involves maintaining the proper 'pull' and preventing secondary complications. (r1) Buck's is non-invasive skin traction; skin breakdown is the #1 risk. (r2) Skeletal pins go through bone; osteomyelitis is the #1 risk. (r3) Halo vests protect the spine; the wrench is for emergency access to the chest for CPR. (r4) Bryant's requires the child's butt to be suspended for effective weight distribution.
rationale.incorrect: Patients in traction should NOT have their weights removed or the traction released by the nurse for transfers; weights must hang freely.
clinicalPearls: Always ensure that traction weights are hanging freely and not resting on the floor or the bed frame.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the patient slides down or is uncomfortable, DO NOT lift the weights to move them. This releases the traction and can cause bone misalignment/muscle spasms. Move the patient *without* lifting the weights.

mnemonic.title: T-R-A-C-T-I-O-N
mnemonic.expansion: Temperature (Infection), Ropes hang free, Alignment, Circulation (5 P's), Type of traction, Increase fluid, Overhead trapeze, No weights on floor.

reviewUnits.heading: Orthopedic Nursing Interventions
reviewUnits.body: Nurses perform CMS checks (Circulation, Motion, Sensation) every 2-4 hours. Any changes (Paresthesia, Cold skin, No pulse) are emergencies (Compartment Syndrome).
